newsitem.title: GREECE: GREEK STOCKS FIRM ON UPBEAT BANKS, THIN TRADE.
newsitem.headline: GREEK STOCKS FIRM ON UPBEAT BANKS, THIN TRADE.

text.p: Greek stocks gained ground in lethargic trade on Tuesday, helped by upbeat banking stocks which recovered from recent lows.
Analysts said the market was moving sideways in slack volume with investors being sidelined but prospects were positive and sentiment remained optimistic.

"The market is directionless in thin trading as investors are either sidelined or engage in quiet stock picking in non-bank large and mid-cap stocks," said Maria Lentziou, an analyst at Olympic Securities.
Tuesday's turnover was subdued, amounting to 11.9 billion drachmas on volume of 5.1 million shares, which included block trades.

"Investors are in a wait-and-see mood, but sentiment is good and prospects remain positive," said Takis Niarchos, an analyst at Hellenic-American Securities. "I expect buying interest to pick up soon, with foreign buying playing a more active role."
Easing short-term interbank rates were expected to favourably affect equities despite a halt in the drop of CPI inflation.
"The market has already digested indications of a difficulty in bringing consumer price inflation below current levels in coming months," said Olympic's Lentziou.
A Reuters poll among 15 bankers and economists produced a mean and median 5.4 percent forecast for Greek consumer inflation in June, unchanged from May.
"Easing interbank rates will greatly help sentiment, starting from banks which already started to recover from recent price fluctuations," she said.
On Tuesday, one-month Athibor, Greece's reference interbank rate, eased 49 basis points to 10.98 percent on improved liquidity conditions.
The Athens general index added 0.43 percent or 6.56 points to 1,525.07 from Monday's 1,518.51 close, trading tightly between 1,515 and 1,527 points.
Banks led the market with a 0.87 percent climb, which outweighed a 1.07 percent drop in construction.
Industrials were virtually flat, slipping 0.01 percent.
Blocks were traded in Piraeus leasing , total 75,000 shares at 4,215 drachmas, and Eltrak , 1,196,000 shares at 895.
Decliners led advancers 106 to 98 with 25 shares unchanged on 229 traded.
OTE telecom Global Depository Shares (GDS) were quoted at London's SEAQ International market at $11.50-$11.90. Two GDSs make up one share of OTE.
The Merrill Lynch call spread warrant on OTE with a strike price of 3,800 drachmas, capped at 5,000 drachmas, was quoted at 1,116-1,146 drachmas.

The recently launched second Merrill Lynch call spread warrant on OTE with a strike price of 6,800 drachmas, capped at 10,000 drachmas, was quoted at 1,160-1,220 drachmas. The warrants expire December 16, 1998. Shares of the underlying instrument firmed 50 drachmas to 6,500.
The Merrill Lynch American call warrant on a basket of 23 Greek equities that are part of the Athens general index was quoted at 575.64-612.39 drachmas. The warrants expire January 9 1998.

The ING Baring Financial Products American style call warrant based on a basket of six bank stocks was quoted at $66.01-$67.71. The strike price is set at $99.60 and the warrants expire October 8, 1997.

The ING Baring Financial Products American-style call warrant on a basket of six blue-chips denominated in drachmas was quoted at 3,074-3,289 drachmas. The strike price is set at 10,000 drachmas and the warrants expire on February 2, 1998.
The ING Baring American-style second call warrant on a basket of six bank stocks was quoted at $9.82-N/O. The strike price is set at $110.0 and the warrants expire April 9 1998.

The recently launched ING Baring American-style, drachma- denominated call warrant on the bourse's benchmark index was quoted at 204-235 drachmas. The strike price is set at 1,639 points and the warrants expire May 14 1998. --Angelos Kiosklis, Athens Newsroom +301 3311812-4
